values.description: Do not terminate Gazebo instantly when the lost person was found. We need some time to make sure that the BOO report has been logged in.
values.title: Gazebo termination

summary.raw: Do not terminate Gazebo instantly when the lost person was found. We need some time to make sure that the BOO report has been logged in.
summary.html: Do not terminate Gazebo instantly when the lost person was found. We need some time to make sure that the BOO report has been logged in.

values.description:
Lost person moves according to probabilities that are printed out. Gradually diffuses towards lower altitude and takes into account the type of terrain. Velocity magnitude is currently not working as we intended it to as a scaling factor to the velocity, so we need to fix that still (Or if it's working it's not making a noticeable difference). 

Commit Messages: 

* First commit

* fixed that dumb bug...

* Lost Person model moves based on given goals. Just need to use the JSON data to give proper goals.

* Added pseudocode

* small changes, more specific pseudocode

* transition matrix changes

* Commented out anything related to JSON because it's not related to osrf but was kept because it's still important if we were to use our own pre-given model.'

* First combined instance

* Tried to add some print statements for determining a new goal, but it doesn't seem to work properly. Can't get the previous things to open properly

* Fixed small merge conflicts.

* Removed redeclaration of Time variables in LPController header file.

* Added random probabilities and the controller works. However, we slide down a hill because we're not offering any resistance, so we need to address that issue.

* Merging osrf code to work properly with ours

* The velocity Magnitude doesn't affect how fast the lost person is moving, so we need to change that. Lost person moves based on probabilities properly (as long as its within the search area).
values.title: Basic Lost Person Model

summary.raw:
Lost person moves according to probabilities that are printed out. Gradually diffuses towards lower altitude and takes into account the type of terrain. Velocity magnitude is currently not working as we intended it to as a scaling factor to the velocity, so we need to fix that still (Or if it's working it's not making a noticeable difference). 

Commit Messages: 

* First commit

* fixed that dumb bug...

* Lost Person model moves based on given goals. Just need to use the JSON data to give proper goals.

* Added pseudocode

* small changes, more specific pseudocode

* transition matrix changes

* Commented out anything related to JSON because it's not related to osrf but was kept because it's still important if we were to use our own pre-given model.'

* First combined instance

* Tried to add some print statements for determining a new goal, but it doesn't seem to work properly. Can't get the previous things to open properly

* Fixed small merge conflicts.

* Removed redeclaration of Time variables in LPController header file.

* Added random probabilities and the controller works. However, we slide down a hill because we're not offering any resistance, so we need to address that issue.

* Merging osrf code to work properly with ours

* The velocity Magnitude doesn't affect how fast the lost person is moving, so we need to change that. Lost person moves based on probabilities properly (as long as its within the search area).
summary.html:
Lost person moves according to probabilities that are printed out. Gradually diffuses towards lower altitude and takes into account the type of terrain. Velocity magnitude is currently not working as we intended it to as a scaling factor to the velocity, so we need to fix that still (Or if it's working it's not making a noticeable difference).

Commit Messages:

  • First commit

  • fixed that dumb bug...

  • Lost Person model moves based on given goals. Just need to use the JSON data to give proper goals.

  • Added pseudocode

  • small changes, more specific pseudocode

  • transition matrix changes

  • Commented out anything related to JSON because it's not related to osrf but was kept because it's still important if we were to use our own pre-given model.'

  • First combined instance

  • Tried to add some print statements for determining a new goal, but it doesn't seem to work properly. Can't get the previous things to open properly

  • Fixed small merge conflicts.

  • Removed redeclaration of Time variables in LPController header file.

  • Added random probabilities and the controller works. However, we slide down a hill because we're not offering any resistance, so we need to address that issue.

  • Merging osrf code to work properly with ours

  • The velocity Magnitude doesn't affect how fast the lost person is moving, so we need to change that. Lost person moves based on probabilities properly (as long as its within the search area).

values.description:
First version of the lost person controller. Courtesy of BYU.

 @dnorth2 Notice that I've made the following changes:

* Your lost person controller is now compiled and install it when you compile and install the main swarm libraries. It's no longer living in the `example` directory anymore. From now on, you should work on the files located in `include/swarm/LostPersonControllerPlugin.hh` and `src/LostPersonControllerPlugin.cc`.

* I removed some warnings in the code. Take a look at `LostPersonControllerPlugin.cc:256` too. I added a `return 0` to make sure that the function always return an integer. Please, review if that's correct.
values.title: Lost person controller (v1)

summary.raw:
First version of the lost person controller. Courtesy of BYU.

 @dnorth2 Notice that I've made the following changes:

* Your lost person controller is now compiled and install it when you compile and install the main swarm libraries. It's no longer living in the `example` directory anymore. From now on, you should work on the files located in `include/swarm/LostPersonControllerPlugin.hh` and `src/LostPersonControllerPlugin.cc`.

* I removed some warnings in the code. Take a look at `LostPersonControllerPlugin.cc:256` too. I added a `return 0` to make sure that the function always return an integer. Please, review if that's correct.
summary.html:
First version of the lost person controller. Courtesy of BYU.

@dnorth2 Notice that I've made the following changes:

  • Your lost person controller is now compiled and install it when you compile and install the main swarm libraries. It's no longer living in the example directory anymore. From now on, you should work on the files located in include/swarm/LostPersonControllerPlugin.hh and src/LostPersonControllerPlugin.cc.

  • I removed some warnings in the code. Take a look at LostPersonControllerPlugin.cc:256 too. I added a return 0 to make sure that the function always return an integer. Please, review if that's correct.

values.description: And added a message in the default team controller plugin to confirm that the plugin was loaded.
values.title: Disable debug output in LostPersonControllerPlugin

summary.raw: And added a message in the default team controller plugin to confirm that the plugin was loaded.
summary.html: And added a message in the default team controller plugin to confirm that the plugin was loaded.

values.description:
1. Moved the `swarmlog_to_csv_comms.py` into the ruby script.

2. The ruby script can now upload logs to gazebosim.org. See http://gazebosim.org/swarm. The site is password protected for now.

New script usage:

* -p <pass_code> : This parameter is required for uploading data to gazebosim.org. 

* -u <dir>: Upload all the logs in the provided directory. This will *not* run tests.

* -g <dir>: Generate reports for all the logs in the provided directory. This will *not* run tests.

If -u and -g are not provided, then the script will run tests, generate reports, and upload the data (as long as the passcode is provided).
values.title: Update the ruby script

summary.raw:
1. Moved the `swarmlog_to_csv_comms.py` into the ruby script.

2. The ruby script can now upload logs to gazebosim.org. See http://gazebosim.org/swarm. The site is password protected for now.

New script usage:

* -p <pass_code> : This parameter is required for uploading data to gazebosim.org. 

* -u <dir>: Upload all the logs in the provided directory. This will *not* run tests.

* -g <dir>: Generate reports for all the logs in the provided directory. This will *not* run tests.

If -u and -g are not provided, then the script will run tests, generate reports, and upload the data (as long as the passcode is provided).
summary.html:
1. Moved the swarmlog_to_csv_comms.py into the ruby script.

  2. The ruby script can now upload logs to gazebosim.org. See http://gazebosim.org/swarm. The site is password protected for now.

New script usage:

  • -p <pass_code> : This parameter is required for uploading data to gazebosim.org.

  • -u <dir>: Upload all the logs in the provided directory. This will not run tests.

  • -g <dir>: Generate reports for all the logs in the provided directory. This will not run tests.

If -u and -g are not provided, then the script will run tests, generate reports, and upload the data (as long as the passcode is provided).

values.description:
Add  a Python API for writing vehicle controllers.

Borrows heavily from @dsaldana's work: https://github.com/dsaldana/swarm_python.

Tutorial explaining how to try this out: #!/osrf/swarm/wiki/Tutorial-15-Write_a_controller_in_Python

Most of the C++ API is exposed. More could be done on that front.
values.title: Add Python API

summary.raw:
Add  a Python API for writing vehicle controllers.

Borrows heavily from @dsaldana's work: https://github.com/dsaldana/swarm_python.

Tutorial explaining how to try this out: #!/osrf/swarm/wiki/Tutorial-15-Write_a_controller_in_Python

Most of the C++ API is exposed. More could be done on that front.
summary.html:
Add a Python API for writing vehicle controllers.

Borrows heavily from @dsaldana's work: https://github.com/dsaldana/swarm_python.

Tutorial explaining how to try this out: #!/osrf/swarm/wiki/Tutorial-15-Write_a_controller_in_Python

Most of the C++ API is exposed. More could be done on that front.

values.reason: Looking into other solutions for solving our performance problems using a terrain.

values.description:
* For each existing `final_XXX_<num_robots>.world` file, there's now a flat version with the suffix `final_XXX_flat_<num_robots>.world`
* In you're using a world with a flat terrain, your log header will have a value of `None` for the field `terrain_name`.
* `run_swarm.rb` accepts a new option `--flat` for running experiments with flat worlds.
values.title: Flat terrains

summary.raw:
* For each existing `final_XXX_<num_robots>.world` file, there's now a flat version with the suffix `final_XXX_flat_<num_robots>.world`
* In you're using a world with a flat terrain, your log header will have a value of `None` for the field `terrain_name`.
* `run_swarm.rb` accepts a new option `--flat` for running experiments with flat worlds.
summary.html:
• For each existing final_XXX_<num_robots>.world file, there's now a flat version with the suffix final_XXX_flat_<num_robots>.world
  • In you're using a world with a flat terrain, your log header will have a value of None for the field terrain_name.
  • run_swarm.rb accepts a new option --flat for running experiments with flat worlds.

values.description:
Adds independent controller update rates for each vehicle type.

This is motivated by the inability of using low update rates (10 Hz) in the controllers of the rotorcrafts and fixed wings.
values.title: Independent controller update rates

summary.raw:
Adds independent controller update rates for each vehicle type.

This is motivated by the inability of using low update rates (10 Hz) in the controllers of the rotorcrafts and fixed wings.
summary.html:
Adds independent controller update rates for each vehicle type.

This is motivated by the inability of using low update rates (10 Hz) in the controllers of the rotorcrafts and fixed wings.

values.description:
Make Swarm compatible with Gazebo 6.x and 7.x and apply some changes required by GTRI.

Note that the `max_step_size` change is not required by GTRI but it boosts simulation a lot, so I'd like to test it with this value.
values.title: Compatibility with Gazebo7

summary.raw:
Make Swarm compatible with Gazebo 6.x and 7.x and apply some changes required by GTRI.

Note that the `max_step_size` change is not required by GTRI but it boosts simulation a lot, so I'd like to test it with this value.
summary.html:
Make Swarm compatible with Gazebo 6.x and 7.x and apply some changes required by GTRI.

Note that the max_step_size change is not required by GTRI but it boosts simulation a lot, so I'd like to test it with this value.

values.description:
This pull request extends `swarmlog` with the `--filter <output>` option. It takes an existing log file and export it to `output` copying only the entries that were saved by the `broker` or the `boo`. 

E.g.:

```
#!python

swarmlog -f swarm.log --filter /tmp/swarm_filtered.log
```

Note: this PR is built atop pull request #113, which should be merged first. [Here's a better diff](#!/osrf/swarm/branches/compare/swarmlog_filter%0Dgazebo7#diff).
values.title: Export a log file containing only "boo" and "broker" entries

summary.raw:
This pull request extends `swarmlog` with the `--filter <output>` option. It takes an existing log file and export it to `output` copying only the entries that were saved by the `broker` or the `boo`. 

E.g.:

```
#!python

swarmlog -f swarm.log --filter /tmp/swarm_filtered.log
```

Note: this PR is built atop pull request #113, which should be merged first. [Here's a better diff](#!/osrf/swarm/branches/compare/swarmlog_filter%0Dgazebo7#diff).
summary.html:
This pull request extends swarmlog with the --filter <output> option. It takes an existing log file and export it to output copying only the entries that were saved by the broker or the boo.

E.g.:

swarmlog -f swarm.log --filter /tmp/swarm_filtered.log

Note: this PR is built atop pull request #113, which should be merged first. Here's a better diff.

* Reduced the size of the terrain image
* Disable robotplugin logging by default.
